content.webTitle: Review: Lullabies for Little Criminals by Heather O'Neill

fields.headline: Lullabies for Little Criminals
fields.bodyText: Definitely not a feelgood book - 12-year-old Baby, growing up in the red light district of Montreal with her 26-year-old junky father, moves between foster homes and detention centres, finally ending up on the streets as a hooker. Heather O’Neill’s novel is harrowing, but Patricia Rodriguez’s portrayal of a 12-year-old’s extraordinarily adult attitude to both her father, who calls heroin “chocolate milk”, and her dysfunctional childhood is sympathetic and compelling. • This article was amended on 11 October 2016 to clarify that Lullabies for Little Criminals was written by Heather O’Neill and read by Patricia Rodriguez
